quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Countries and Day
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, caesar, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: These countries are all republics except one. Which one is a kingdom?
Three of these countries are Islamic republics. Which one is a kingdom?
On what day in March was Julius Caesar assassinated?
According to the Roman calendar, in which of these months did the day of ides fall on the same day as in March ?
What is the proper name of Queen Elizabeth IIs realm?

options.text: The Kingdom of Great Britain, Ireland and Scotland
The Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

questions.question: In the Roman calendar, every month had a particular day called ides.
Three of these countries are kingdoms. One is a republic. Which one is it?
When did the Carpathia arrive in New York with the rescued survivors of the RMS Titanic?
In what year was Julius Caesar killed?
On 15 September, 1973 King Carl XVI Gustaf became the ruler of which of these modern kingdoms?
Three of these countries are kingdoms, which one is actually a sultanate?
In the Roman calendar, what did the day called ides mark each month?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The full moon

questions.question: Jock Hume, violinist with the orchestra on board the Titanic, perished when the ship sank. What did the agency that employed the musician send to his family after the disaster?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A bill

questions.question: Where was the Carpathia headed when the distress call from Titanic was transmitted?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mediterranean Cruise

questions.question: A dog show was planned on board the Titanic for April 15th.

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: January and Julius Caesar
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, assassins, patricks. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: From the Halls of Montezuma
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Marines hymn

questions.question: Where did the assassination of Julius Caesar take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Pompey Theatre

questions.question: St. Patricks Day is traditionally a feast day celebrating the Patron Saint of what country?
The United States Marine Corps is a Department of the United States Army.
Green has always been the color associated with St. Patricks Day.
The first American St. Patricks Day Parade was held in Boston, Massachusetts.
The first St. Patricks Day parade organized in the Irish Free State was held in 1931 in what city?

During the battle of Belleau Wood, the U.S. Marines fierceness and toughness earned them the respect of the Germans, who rated them of storm-trooper quality. What nickname did the U.S. Marines reportedly earn in this battle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Devil Dogs

questions.question: Two significant earthquakes occurred on January 17. The first was a 6.7 magnitude earthquake in Northbridge, California. The second was a 7.3 magnitude earthquake near Kobe, Japan. In what two consecutive years did they occur?
Which famous boxer, born on January 17, won a gold medal in the 1960 Olympics?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Muhammad Ali

questions.question: On January 17, 2006, this person became the second oldest inmate to be executed in the United States since 1976.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Clarence Ray Allen

questions.question: Benjamin Franklin, famous statesman and inventor, was born on January 17 of what year?
This actress, who played on The Golden Girls, was born On January 17, 1922.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Betty White

questions.question: Award-winning American author Robert Cormier died on January 17.
Julius Caesar was struck down by his assassins while on his way to what location?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Temple of Venus

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Country and City
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, patricks, country. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The head office of the European Central Bank, established on June 1, 1998, is located in which city?
This treaty was signed on February 7, 1992 by the members of the European Community, resulting in the creation of the European Union.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maastricht Treaty

questions.question: The Council of Europe and the Council of the European Union are one and the same body.
The players of which of these baseball teams do NOT wear green uniforms on St. Patricks Day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pittsburgh Pirates

questions.question: All euro coins have a common side showing the denomination and a national side showing an image specifically chosen by the country that issued it.
Las Vegas is situated in a high desert valley roughly 2,500 feet above sea level. What provides its main source of water?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Colorado River

questions.question: The European Court of Justice, the Supreme Court of the European Union, is based in which country?
In what city does the largest St. Patricks Day Parade take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York

questions.question: The European Economic Community, informally called the Common Market, was established by the Treaty of Rome in what year?
Which statement about the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, is true?

options.text: It is one of the three main institutions governing the European Union
The Commission is divided into departments known as Directorates-General (DG)

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What institution of the European Union is directly elected by EU citizens once every five years?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The European Parliament

questions.question: In this city, St. Patricks Day is celebrated in bars such as the Silver Dollar Saloon, the MM Cigar Store, The Irish Times Pub and the traditional parade is led by the Ancient Order of Hibernians.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Butte, Montana

questions.question: This country opted to stay out of the European Community during a referendum in 1972. On the next referendum, held in 1994, its people rejected the proposal to join the European Union.
More than 300,000 marchers participated in the 2006 St. Patricks Day Parade in New York City.
In the past St. Patricks Day was celebrated only as a strictly religious holiday. When did it become a public holiday?

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Las Vegas and Oklahoma
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, lodge, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of these Nike events took place before the 90s?

options.text: Six NIKE athletes help win the Olympic gold medal in basketball.
NIKE launches P.L.A.Y. - Participate in the Lives of Americas Youth - a call to action for everyone to help kids get and stay active.
NIKE establishes Athletics West, a safe house for world-class athletes to train for Olympic competition.
NIKEs Reuse-A-Shoe breaks ground by recycling old athletic shoes into material for resurfacing sports courts.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: NIKE establishes Athletics West, a safe house for world-class athletes to train for Olympic competition.

questions.question: What is Y-3?

options.text: The mechanism of a Nike watch
A new cushioning technology from Nike
A collaboration between Adidas and designer Yohji Yamamoto

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A collaboration between Adidas and designer Yohji Yamamoto

questions.question: Oklahoma means “Home of the Red Man” in which Native American language?
Which casino-hotel in Las Vegas opened on April 28, 2005 and at the time of its completion was the largest privately-funded construction project in the U.S.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wynn Las Vegas

questions.question: The area code for Las Vegas is 702. This was the code for all of Nevada until 1996. What is now the area code for the rest of the state?
What Las Vegas building, completed in 1996, offers two observation decks, a revolving restaurant, and  thrill rides?
Out in the Mojave desert, Las Vegas is far from any other metropolitan areas. Which is the closest?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Los Angeles

questions.question: If you travel southeast from Las Vegas, youre heading toward two tourist attractions. One is 35 miles away, the other is a couple hundred miles further. Name them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hoover Dam, Grand Canyon

questions.question: What city was the first state capital of Oklahoma?
Nike started the Just Do It? campaign in this year.
Which of the following is the major interstate highway running through Las Vegas?
Adidas acquired the Salomon Group with the brands Salomon, TaylorMade, Mavic and Bonfire in December 1997. What is the name of the new company?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Adidas-Salomon AG.

questions.question: Only part of The Las Vegas Strip is located within Las Vegas.
Adidas was a company of two brothers. In 1948 one of them - Rudolf,  left it and created his own brand. Which is it?
Which of these is the mountain that boasts a skiing area, a lodge complete with cabins, hiking trails, and alpine terrain all within 50 miles of the center of the Las Vegas valley?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mt. Charleston

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Year and Term
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, tears, committee. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What measures, related to Native American tribes, did the National Collegiate Athletic Association take in 2005?

options.text: They founded a scholarship for Native American athletes.
They banned the abusive Native American imagery and nicknames in athletics.
They allowed Native American teams to take part in tournaments.
They created the Native American Soccer League.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They banned the abusive Native American imagery and nicknames in athletics.

questions.question: In what year did Oklahoma enter the union as the 46th state?
Which of these names doesnt refer to the U.S. federal legislation that restored Native American self-government on a tribal basis in 1934?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Curtis Act

questions.question: Members of what Native American nation live on the Cheyenne River Indian Reservation?
This incident took place on June 26, 1975 on the Pine Ridge reservation and was later depicted in Michael Apteds 1992 movie Incident at Oglala.

options.text: Leonard Peltier and two FBI agents died of an unknown disease on the Pine Ridge reservation.
The bodies of two FBI agents were found in Leonard Peltiers backyard.
Two FBI agents were shot in a shootout and Leonard Peltier was convicted.
Two FBI agents were found guilty for the murder of Leonard Peltier.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Two FBI agents were shot in a shootout and Leonard Peltier was convicted.

questions.question: Who invented the writing system of the Cherokee language?
When did the Native Americans finally receive U.S. citizenship through The Indian Citizenship Act?
The final version of the Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Continental Congress on July 4, 1776. In which state did this happen?
The term Trail of Tears refers to which of these?

options.text: The wagon trail that settlers followed across Indian and Oklahoma Territories during the 19th century.
The route of the old cattle drives that crossed the Oklahoma panhandle between Texas and Dodge City, Kansas.
The stretch of I-35 between Norman and the Cotton Bowl Stadium in Dallas when the University of Oklahoma football team plays the University of Texas.
The forced relocation of the Choctaws in 1831 and the Cherokees in 1838 from the southeastern United States.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The forced relocation of the Choctaws in 1831 and the Cherokees in 1838 from the southeastern United States.

questions.question: Which of the following was not taught to Native American children at Indian boarding schools during the 19th century and early 20th century?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Native American languages

questions.question: What is the original meaning of the term Sooner, which came into use in 1889 according to the Oklahoma Historical Society?

options.text: Its the name of the first commercial oil well drilled in Oklahoma Territory in 1897.
A person who tried to settle in the Unassigned Lands before they were opened for settlement.
A person who settled legally in the Unassigned Lands.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A person who tried to settle in the Unassigned Lands before they were opened for settlement.

questions.question: According to a law, Native Americans were not allowed to enter Boston until which year?
Which one of these is not a group belonging to the Apache nation?
The forced relocation of the Cherokee and the Choctaw to the western states, resulting in the death of 4,000 Native Americans, is known by what name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Trail of Tears

questions.question: Although the whole Committee of Five participated in the drafting of the US Declaration of Independence, this man was the principal author of the Declaration.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Delegates and Independence
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, independence, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Games of what popular US sport are usually part of the July 4th celebrations?
In the 1948 musical film, Easter Parade, Fred Astaire co-stars with which famous actress?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Judy Garland

questions.question: Pepsi 400 is the name of what major annual sports event held on July 4th, or the Saturday of the July 4th weekend?

options.text: A series of extreme sports events

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Car racing

questions.question: The Syng inkstand used to sign the United States Declaration of Independence, was also used in the signing of what other important US document?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The United States Constitution

questions.question: Each year the celebrations of Independence Day in Coney Island, Brooklyn, New York City include this unusual contest.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hot Dog Eating Contest

questions.question: Easter is one of the most important religious holidays of the Christian liturgical year.  What does Easter celebrate?

options.text: The revelation of God to humankind

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The resurrection of Jesus

questions.question: Complete these lyrics from the popular Easter song, Here Comes Peter Cottontail:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: an Easter bonnet too

questions.question: The Liberty Bell, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is an item of great historic significance for all Americans. On July 8, 1776 the bell was tolled for several hours, for what reason?

options.text: To summon the locals to hear the reading of the Declaration of Independence
To summon the locals for the first celebration of Independence Day
To celebrate the signing of the Lee Resolution

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To summon the locals to hear the reading of the Declaration of Independence

questions.question: The US Declaration of Independence and a fictional treasure map on its back are the subject of what popular 2004 film?

options.text: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: National Treasure

questions.question: Which of these American cities got the nickname Americas Most Patriotic Town as a result of having the oldest Independence Day celebrations?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bristol, Rhode Island

questions.question: Which popular flower, native to Japan, is a symbol of the Easter holiday?
Almost half of the 56 delegates who signed the US Declaration of Independence were representatives of what profession?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lawyers and jurists

questions.question: Which term refers to an Easter egg, decorated by the written-wax batik method?
Fifteen days after the signing of the Declaration, the Congress ordered a copy to be engrossed for the delegates of the colonies to sign. Who was the first person to sign this copy?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Hancock

questions.question: The Declaration of Independence was signed by a total of 56 delegates, representing how many colonies?
